title: The Silk Road: Connecting the ancient world through trade - Shannon Harris Castelo

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the Silk Road?

options.label: B
options.text: To establish trade routes between civilizations

options.label: C
options.text: To conquer and dominate neighboring territories

options.label: D
options.text: To promote cultural exchange and understanding

options.label: B
options.text: The transmission of gunpowder to the Middle East

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: By facilitating the transmission of crossbow technology to the Middle East

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It was a precursor to the modern global economy

options.label: B
options.text: It was a response to the challenges of globalization

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on globalization

options.label: A
options.text: By promoting the spread of Buddhism to China and Japan

options.label: B
options.text: By facilitating the transmission of gunpowder to the Middle East

options.label: C
options.text: By introducing Roman glassware to China

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Silk Road on the Roman Empire?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It had a minimal impact on the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the rise of a single dominant world power

options.label: A
options.text: It was a precursor to the modern global economy

options.label: B

title: How does your brain respond to pain? - Karen D. Davis

multiple-choice.question: How does pain affect the ability to complete a task?

options.label: B
options.text: Pain has no effect on task completion.

options.label: C
options.text: Pain distracts and slows down task completion.

multiple-choice.question: What is pain?

options.label: A
options.text: A pleasant sensory and emotional experience.

options.label: B
options.text: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

options.label: C
options.text: A physical sensation without emotional impact.

options.label: D
options.text: A mental state without physical sensation.

multiple-choice.question: What creates the perception of pain intensity and character?

options.label: A
options.text: Special tissue damage-sensing nerve cells called nociceptors.

options.label: C
options.text: The salience network and modulation networks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the salience network in the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: To decide what to pay attention to.

multiple-choice.question: What are modulation networks responsible for in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Delivering pain signals to the cortex.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to find a single treatment for pain that works for everyone?

options.label: A
options.text: Because pain is a simple physical sensation.

options.label: B
options.text: Because pain is a complex experience that affects different people in different ways.

options.label: C
options.text: Because pain is not a significant health issue.

options.label: D
options.text: Because pain is not a treatable condition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of new treatments for pain that directly stimulate or block certain pain-sensing attention or modulation networks?
How do researchers use tools like magnetic resonance imaging to develop new treatments for pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To map brain pathways and tailor treatments to individual patients.

options.label: B
options.text: To test treatments on large groups of patients.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the physical causes of pain.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to understand how the brain responds to pain?

options.label: B
options.text: To study the physical causes of pain.

options.label: C
options.text: To find the best treatment for each individual patient.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the emotional impact of pain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of personalized medicine in treating pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a single treatment that works for everyone.

options.label: B
options.text: To tailor treatments to individual patients based on how their brains respond to pain.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the physical causes of pain.

title: How languages evolve - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the biblical story of the Tower of Babel?

options.label: A
options.text: That all human languages came from a single language spoken by the people of Babel.

options.label: B
options.text: That all of humanity once spoke a single language until they suddenly split into many groups.

options.label: C
options.text: That language was created by God to confuse humans.

options.label: D
options.text: That language is a form of magic that allows humans to communicate with animals.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how did the world's languages come to be so diverse?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a process of gradual language evolution over time.

options.label: B
options.text: Through the migration of people to new lands and the isolation of groups.

options.label: C
options.text: Through the influence of other cultures and the borrowing of words.

options.label: D
options.text: Through the creation of new languages by individual inventors.

multiple-choice.question: What is a protolanguage?

options.label: A
options.text: A language that is still spoken today.

options.label: B
options.text: A language that is considered to be the most ancient language.

options.label: C
options.text: A language that is the common ancestor of a group of languages.

options.label: D
options.text: A language that is used for communication between different languages.

multiple-choice.question: What is a language family?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of languages that are not related to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of languages that are related to each other through a common ancestor.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of languages that are spoken in a specific geographic region.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of languages that are used for communication between different cultures.

multiple-choice.question: How do linguists determine whether languages are related?

options.label: C
options.text: By comparing basic vocabulary such as pronouns and numbers.

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing the number of speakers of each language.

multiple-choice.question: What is a problem that linguists face when constructing language family trees?

options.label: A
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding where the branches at the bottom should end.

options.label: B
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are related.

options.label: C
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are not related.

options.label: D
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are extinct.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to determine the number of languages in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is no clear way of defining what a language is.

options.label: B
options.text: Because languages are constantly evolving and changing over time.

options.label: C
options.text: Because languages are not neatly divided into categories.

options.label: D
options.text: Because languages are not spoken by living people.

multiple-choice.question: What is a super family in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of languages that are not related to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of languages that are related to each other through a common ancestor.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of languages that are spoken in a specific geographic region.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of languages that are used for communication between different cultures.

multiple-choice.question: What is a problem that linguists face when trying to determine the relationships between languages?

options.label: A
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are related.

options.label: B
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are not related.

options.label: C
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are extinct.

options.label: D
options.text: That there is no clear way of deciding which languages are spoken by living people.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it possible that we may never be able to determine how language came about?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is no clear evidence of the origins of language.

options.label: B
options.text: Because language is a complex and evolving phenomenon.

options.label: C
options.text: Because language is not a fixed entity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because language is not a human invention.

options.text: A leader is someone who is responsible for making decisions, while a manager is someone who is responsible for implementing decisions.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: How the heart actually pumps blood - Edmond Hui

multiple-choice.question: What was Leonardo da Vinci's attitude towards studying the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: He was very interested and made significant discoveries about its function.

options.label: B
options.text: He gave up studying it due to its complexity.

options.label: C
options.text: He was neutral and didn't have an opinion about it.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not interested in studying it at all.

multiple-choice.question: Why was it difficult to see the heart valves working?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the heart was a four-chambered organ and it was hard to visualize.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the blood itself is opaque and the blood vessels are hard to see through.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the heart was too small to see.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the heart was too complex to understand.

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct description of the circulation of blood in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: Mammals have a dual-circulation: one with blood going to the lungs and back, and another to the body and back.

options.label: B
options.text: Mammals have a figure-eight circulation: blood goes from one heart pump to the lungs, back to the second heart pump, which sends it to the body, and then back to the first pump.

options.label: C
options.text: Mammals have a single circulation that goes from the heart to the lungs and then to the body.

options.label: D
options.text: Mammals have a circulation that goes from the heart to the body and then back to the heart.

multiple-choice.question: What is necessary to make a heart pump when it is immersed in water?

options.label: A
options.text: To cut off the two atria and trim them down to the tops of the ventricles.

options.label: B
options.text: To squeeze the heart by hand.

options.label: C
options.text: To run water into the right ventricle from a tap.

options.label: D
options.text: To do nothing, as the heart will pump on its own.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the ventricular valves when the ventricle is squeezed?

options.label: A
options.text: They try to close against the incoming stream of water.

options.label: B
options.text: They open up and allow water to flow into the ventricle.

options.label: C
options.text: They leak and allow water to escape from the ventricle.

options.label: D
options.text: They remain closed and do not allow water to flow into the ventricle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the ventricular valves closing against each other when the ventricle is squeezed?

options.label: A
options.text: They leak and allow water to escape from the ventricle.

options.label: B
options.text: They remain closed and do not allow water to flow into the ventricle.

options.label: C
options.text: They are worn out and need to be replaced.

options.label: D
options.text: They close with very little wear and tear.

multiple-choice.question: How many beats does a heart give in its lifetime?
What is the purpose of the two major heart arteries: the aorta and pulmonary artery?

options.label: A
options.text: To carry blood from the heart to the lungs and then to the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To carry blood from the heart to the body and then back to the heart.

options.label: C
options.text: To carry blood from the heart to the lungs and then back to the heart.

options.label: D
options.text: To carry blood from the heart to the body and then to the lungs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of running water into the right ventricle from a tap?

options.label: A
options.text: The ventricle inflates with water and a stream of water squirts out of the pulmonary artery.

options.label: B
options.text: The ventricle does not inflate with water and no water squirts out of the pulmonary artery.

options.label: C
options.text: The ventricle leaks and allows water to escape from the pulmonary artery.

options.label: D
options.text: The ventricular valves do not open and allow water to flow into the ventricle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of understanding how the heart works?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no significance and is just a complex organ.

options.label: B
options.text: It is only important for medical professionals.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives new resonance to the feeling you get when you run a race, drink too much caffeine or catch the eye of the one you love.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important for people who study biology.

title: Lessons from Auschwitz: The power of our words - Benjamin Zander

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It means she should never say anything that could be misinterpreted.

options.label: C
options.text: It means she should always think before she speaks.
